title: Applied Computer Concept
description: Computer skills course which assumes no prior experience with computers. Introduces computer concepts and word processing; spreadsheets and database software; and examines societal issues. Graduation credit may be earned for CS 108 or CMIS 108; but not for both.

title: Concepts of Computer Science
description: Broad view of computer science: hardware; operating systems; software design and development; algorithms; networks; and applications.

title: Introduction to Computing I
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 120 Minimum Grade of C OR MATH 120E Minimum Grade of C OR MATH 120I Minimum Grade of C OR MATH 120E Minimum Grade of C
description: Programming course that assumes basic computer literacy. Introduces a high-level programming language and basic problem solving. IAI Course CS 911.

title: Introduction to Computing for Engineers
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 150 Minimum Grade of C AND
description: Introduces C++ programming and basic problem solving. Focuses on computer applications in engineering, science and numeric methods. Prerequisite: Basic computer literacy.

title: Introduction to Computing II
prerequisitesRaw: CS 140 Minimum Grade of C AND
description: Algorithmic problem solving with a modern programming language. Language syntax; basic design methods; algorithms; and abstraction. IAI Course CS 912.

title: Computer Science Work Experience I
description: Supervised work experience with agency employing computer scientists or information specialists. For students with part time cooperative jobs. Limited to students enrolled in more than 6 hours.

title: CS Cooperative Ed Exp I
description: Supervised work experience with agency employing computer scientists or information specialists. First work period of 5-year academic/work experience program.

title: Database and Web System Development
prerequisitesRaw: CS 111 Minimum Grade of C AND CS 150 Minimum Grade of C
description: An introduction to multi-tier software systems and database programming and their application to web-based information storage and retrieval systems.

title: Introduction to Computing III
prerequisitesRaw: CS 150 Minimum Grade of C AND
description: Basic software engineering concepts, elementary data structures and algorithms, fundamentals of object-oriented programming.

title: Introduction to Computer Organization and Architecture
prerequisitesRaw: CS 150 Minimum Grade of C AND
description: Processor, memory, I/O structure of computer systems, data representations, instruction set architecture of typical processor as hardware/software interface, processor implementation, performance evaluation methods.

title: Computer Science Work Experience II
description: Supervised work experience with agency employing computer scientists or information specialists. For students with part-time cooperative jobs. Limited to students enrolled in more than 6 credit hours.

title: Computer Science Cooperative Education Experience II
description: Supervised work experience with agency employing computer scientists or information specialists. Second work period of 5-year academic/work experience program.

title: Operating Systems
prerequisitesRaw: CS 286 Minimum Grade of C AND
description: Processes, threads, and synchronization; I/O and memory management at the hardware and OS levels; file systems; and implementation of basic OS abstractions, concurrent programming.

title: Human-Computer Interaction Design
prerequisitesRaw: CS 234 Minimum Grade of C AND (STAT 244 Minimum Grade of C OR STAT 380 Minimum Grade of C)
description: Design of interactions between people and computers. Interface design, conceptual models, design methods, software evaluation and ethical concerns. Software design project.

title: Software Engineering
prerequisitesRaw: CS 150 Minimum Grade of C AND CS 234 Minimum Grade of C
description: Introduction to the concepts and techniques required to develop complex software systems and manage software projects. Emphasis on object-oriented methodologies and modeling via UML.

title: Programming Languages
prerequisitesRaw: CS 286 Minimum Grade of C AND
description: Design, appropriateness and linguistics issues associated with different programming languages and programming paradigms. Covers syntax and semantics of languages, including BNF Notation.

title: Algorithms and Data Structures
prerequisitesRaw: CS 150 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 224 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 150 Minimum Grade of C
description: Considers appropriate choice of data structures, comparisons of algorithms, recursive algorithms, complexity, and introduction to parallel algorithms.

title: Ethical and Social Implications of Computing
description: An introduction to the social, ethical, legal, and professional contexts in which software systems are developed and utilized.

title: Game Design, Development, and Technology
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 152 Minimum Grade of C AND CS 286 Minimum Grade of C AND CS 321 Minimum Grade of C
description: Introduction to the entire process of game development, including history, social impact, design, programming, software engineering, math, physics, graphics, animation, audio, AI, and hardware.

title: Topics in Computer Science
description: Selected topics in computer science. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours for different topics.

title: Computer Science Work Experience III
description: Supervised work experience with agency employing computer scientists or information specialists. For students with part-time cooperative jobs. Limited to students enrolled in more than 6 credit hours.

title: Computer Science Cooperative Education Experience III
description: Supervised work experience with agency employing computer scientists or information specialists. Third work period of 5-year academic/work experience program.

title: Compiler Construction
prerequisitesRaw: CS 330 Minimum Grade of C AND
description: Translation of programming languages. Emphasis on techniques used in construction of compilers, including lexical analysis, syntactical analysis, type checking, and code generation.

title: Senior Project: Software Design
prerequisitesRaw: CS 340 Minimum Grade of C AND CS 314 Minimum Grade of C AND CS 325 Minimum Grade of C AND CS 360 Minimum Grade of C
description: First part of a two-semester sequence in which teams complete the design and planning stages of a software development project. Selected topics in software development, group dynamics, and project management. Not for Graduate credit.

title: Database Management Systems
prerequisitesRaw: CS 150 Minimum Grade of C AND CS 234 Minimum Grade of C
description: Database management system concepts, models, languages. Entity/relationship, relational and object-oriented data models; relational database design and implementation including SQL; and object databases.

title: Artificial Intelligence
prerequisitesRaw: CS 340 Minimum Grade of C AND
description: Principles and programming techniques of artificial intelligence. Intelligent agents, heuristic programming, knowledge representation, expert systems, and machine learning.

title: Networks and Data Communications
prerequisitesRaw: CS 340 Minimum Grade of C AND (CS 314 Minimum Grade of C OR CS 414 Minimum Grade of C)
description: Concepts of networks and data communications. Networking protocols and architecture; data encoding and transmission; network management; and distributed applications.

title: Theory of Computation
prerequisitesRaw: CS 330 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 224 Minimum Grade of C; or Graduate Standing
description: Theoretical foundations of computer science, including a theory of automata: pushdown automata, Turing machines; and formal languages.

title: Design and Analysis of Algorithms
prerequisitesRaw: CS 340 Minimum Grade of C AND
description: Algorithmic design strategies; Runtime analysis; Greedy; Divide-and-Conquer; Dynamic Programming; Network Flow; Algorithmic Intractability; P vs. NP vs. NP-Complete; Reduction Theory

title: Cryptography
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 224 Minimum Grade of C AND CS 447 Minimum Grade of C
description: Introduction to cryptology, cryptographic primitives, authentication, authorization, and access control, security models, cryptographic protocols, key management and establishment, applications.

title: Bioinformatics Algorithms
prerequisitesRaw: CS 340 Minimum Grade of C AND
description: This course concerns algorithms for bioinformatics problems arising from comparative genomics. Fundamental topics are pairwise sequence alignment, phylogenetic tree construction, and multiple sequence alignment.

title: Computer Graphics
prerequisitesRaw: CS 286 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 152 Minimum Grade of C AND CS 150 Minimum Grade of C
description: Introduction to2D and 3D graphics, graphics hardware, scan conversion, anti-aliasing, hidden components, transformations, projections, ray tracing, curve and surface modeling, and animation.

title: Topics in Computer Science
description: Selected topics in computer science. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours for different topics. Requires consent of instructor.

title: Independent Study
description: Reading and research in specific areas of computer science. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 hours. Requires consent of department chair or program director.

title: Senior Project: Software Implementation
prerequisitesRaw: CS 425 Minimum Grade of C AND
description: Second part of a two-semester sequence in which teams implement, test, and deploy software development project that was planned and designed in CS 425. Includes a formal presentation to the computer science faculty.

title: Writing Lab-Grammar
description: Computerized self-instructional materials for improving writing. GRM is prerequisite to 100R (Rhetoric). Not for English majors or minors.

title: Writing Lab-Rhetoric
prerequisitesRaw: ENG 100G
description: Computerized self-instructional materials for improving writing. Not for English majors or minors.

title: English Composition I
prerequisitesRaw: Evidence-based READ/WRIT Score (S11R) Minimum score of 530 OR ((ACT English (A01) Minimum score of 20 or WRIT/LANGUAGE Test Score (S14) Minimum Score of 27 or ACCUPLACER Writing (UA02) Minimum score of 250 or AD 090 Minimum grade of C) AND (ACT Reading (A03) Minimum score of 18 or Reading Test Score (S13) Minimum score of 24 or ACCUPLACER Reading (UA01) Minimum score of 237 or AD 082 Minimum grade of C or AD 116 Minimum grade of C))
description: Instruction and practice in analyzing and composing the academic expository essay. IAI Course C1 900.

title: English Composition I
description: Instruction and practice in analyzing and composing the academic expository essay.

title: English Composition: Non-Native Speakers
description: Instruction and practice in expository writing, including the paragraph and short essay. Course is a general education skills course. Requires consent of advisor.

title: English Composition II
prerequisitesRaw: ENG 101 Minimum Grade of C OR ENG 101N Minimum Grade of C OR ENG 101E Minimum Grade of C
description: Builds upon the analytical and writing skills developed in 101 with emphasis on argumentation and critical synthesis of information based on research. IAI Course C1 901R.

title: English Composition: Non-Native Speakers
prerequisitesRaw: ENG 101 Minimum Grade of C OR ENG 101N Minimum Grade of C OR ENG 101E Minimum Grade of C
description: Instruction and practice in expository writing, including the essay and research paper. Course is a general education skills course. Requires consent of advisor.

title: Interpersonal Communication Skills
description: Principles and practices of oral communication emphasizing message formation and delivery; listening; perception; awareness of verbal and nonverbal codes; and managing conflict.

title: Reasoning and Argumentation
description: Students will learn to analyze, critically evaluate, and construct arguments. Topics include organizing information, detecting fallacies, analyzing meaning, and using effective methods of argumentation. IAI Course H4 906.

title: Math for Elementary Teaching: Number Sense & Algebra
description: These courses are designed to meet state certification standards for elementary teachers. Number sense and algebra.

title: Math for Elementary Teaching: Probability, Statistics & Geometry
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 112A Minimum Grade of C (concurrency allowed)
description: These courses are designed to meet state certification standards for elementary teachers. Probability, statistics, and geometry.

title: Mathematics for Elementary Teaching
prerequisitesRaw: ALEKS PPL - Math Plcmnt 46 OR (MATH 112A Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 112B Minimum Grade of C)
description: One of three courses designed to meet state certification standards for elementary teachers. College algebra skills essential for elementary teachers.

title: College Algebra
prerequisitesRaw: ALEKS PPL - Math Plcmnt 46
description: Cartesian coordinates; graphing; lines; parabolas; functions; inverses; roots of polynomials; rational functions and inequalities; linear systems; matrices; and determinants.

title: Enhanced College Algebra
prerequisitesRaw: ALEKS PPL - Math Plcmnt 30 OR AD 070 Minimum Grade of C
description: Cartesian coordinates, graphing, lines, parabolas, functions, inverses, roots of polynomials, rational functions and inequalities, linear systems, matrices, and determinants

title: College Algebra
prerequisitesRaw: ALEKS Placement Score < 30 (UL01 of 30 or less).
description: Cartesian coordinates; graphing; lines; parabolas; functions; inverses; roots of polynomials; rational functions and inequalities; linear systems; matrices; and determinants.

title: Precalculus Mathematics with Trigonometry
prerequisitesRaw: ALEKS PPL - Math Plcmnt 61 OR MATH 120 Minimum Grade of C OR MATH 120E Minimum Grade of C OR MATH 120I Minimum Grade of C
description: Exponential and logarithmic functions; trigonometric functions and their applications; inverse trigonometric functions; trigonometric identities and equations; laws of sines and cosines; binomial theorem; and introduction to partial fractions.

title: Calculus for the Life Sciences
prerequisitesRaw: ALEKS PPL - Math Plcmnt 76 OR MATH 125 Minimum Grade of C
description: Fundamental concepts of calculus with applications focused on the life sciences: limits, continuity, derivatives, integrals, fundamental theorem of calculus, partial derivatives, differential equations, and applications. Course not a prerequisite for Math 152.

title: Calculus I
prerequisitesRaw: ALEKS PPL - Math Plcmnt 76 OR MATH 125 Minimum Grade of C AND
description: Fundamental concepts of calculus: limits, continuity, and derivatives. Mean Value Theorem of Calculus, integration techniques, and applications. IAI Course M1 900-1.

title: Calculus II
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 150 Minimum Grade of C AND
description: Applications of integration; techniques of integration; improper integrals; polar coordinates; infinite sequences and series; and Taylor's theorem. IAI Course M1 900-2.

title: Introduction to Programming and Problem Solving
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 150 Minimum Grade of C
description: Introduction to real-world problem solving using a modern computational environment MATLAB. In the context of engineering applications, basic procedural programming concepts will be covered.

title: Logic & Mathematical Reasoning
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 150 Minimum Grade of C AND
description: Concepts and techniques essential to advanced mathematics; logic, methods of proof, sets, relations, induction, functions, cardinality, combinatorics, and graph theory.

title: Discrete Mathematics
prerequisitesRaw: CS 140 Minimum Grade of C
description: Mathematical concepts and techniques essential to computer science: logic; sets; algorithms; methods of proof; induction and recursion; simple counting techniques; and graph theory. Does not count toward a major in mathematics.

title: Calculus III
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 152 Minimum Grade of C
description: Vectors; dot and cross products; lines and planes in space; and vector-valued functions. Partial derivatives, gradient, extrema, and multiple integrals. Theorems of Green, Stokes, and Gauss. IAI Course M1 900-3.

title: History of Mathematics from Antiquity to Descartes
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 125 Minimum Grade of C OR MATH 150 Minimum Grade of C
description: The development of mathematics from antiquity through the development of analytic geometry. Does not count toward a degree in mathematics.

title: Differential Equations I
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 250 Minimum Grade of C
description: First order ordinary differential equations, linear ordinary, differential equations of higher order, systems of first order linear equations, and applications.

title: Teaching of Middle School Mathematics
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 112A Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 112B Minimum Grade of C
description: Constructing instructional objectives; formulating, utilizing and evaluating strategies for teaching mathematical concepts and skills; diagnosis and remediation of students' learning difficulties. Does not count towards a degree in mathematics.

title: The Teaching of Secondary Mathematics 1
description: The first of two courses focusing on the content and pedagogy applicable to secondary mathematics teacher licensure. Does not count toward non-teaching degree or minor in mathematics.

title: Number Theory
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 125 Minimum Grade of C AND
description: Divisibility, primes, numerical functions, congruences, introduction to coding theory, continued fractions, and rational approximations. Does not count toward a degree in mathematics.

title: Introduction to Algebraic Structures
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 223 Minimum Grade of C
description: Introduction to group theory. Groups; subgroups; cyclic groups; cosets and Lagrange's theorem; homomorphisms; and factor groups.

title: Linear Algebra I
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 152 Minimum Grade of C AND
description: Systems of linear equations matrices and determinants; vector spaces and linear transformations. Eigenvalues, eigenvectors, and diagonalization of a symmetric matrix.

title: Theory of Interest
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 152 Minimum Grade of C
description: Measures of interest; annuities; yield rates; amortization schedules and sinking funds; economic rationale for interest; and stochastic approaches to interest.

title: Introduction to Analysis
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 223 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 250 Minimum Grade of C
description: Real numbers. Topology on the real line. Sequences of real numbers; limits of functions, continuity of functions; differentiation.

title: Engineering Mathematics
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 305 Minimum Grade of C
description: Linear algebra: Gaussian elimination, linear independence, vector spaces, eigenvalues; discrete mathematics including: combinations and graph theory; and complex analysis (differentiation, integration, and series).

title: Development of Modern Mathematics
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 152 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 223 Minimum Grade of C
description: The development of mathematics since the discovery of calculus.

title: The Teaching of Secondary Mathematics 2
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 311 Minimum Grade of C
description: The second of two courses focusing on the content and pedagogy applicable to secondary mathematics teacher licensure. Does not count toward non-teaching degree or minor in mathematics.

title: Mathematics Topics for Teachers: Analysis
description: Analysis. May be repeated to a maximum of 3 hours so long as no topic is repeated. May not count toward a concentration or minor in mathematics. Requires consent of instructor.

title: Mathematics Topics for Teachers: Algebra
description: Algebra. May be repeated to a maximum of 3 hours so long as no topic is repeated. May not count toward a concentration or minor in mathematics. Requires consent of instructor.

title: Mathematics Topics for Teachers: Number Theory
description: Number theory. May be repeated to a maximum of 3 hours so long as no topic is repeated. May not count toward a concentration or minor in mathematics. Requires consent of instructor.

title: Mathematics Topics for Teachers: Probability & Statistics
description: Probability and statistics. May be repeated to a maximum of 3 hours so long as no topic is repeated. May not count toward a concentration or minor in mathematics. Requires consent of instructor.

title: Mathematics Topics for Teachers: Mathematical Concepts
description: Mathematical concepts. May be repeated to a maximum of 3 hours so long as no topic is repeated. May not count toward a concentration or minor in mathematics. Requires consent of instructor.

title: Mathematics Topics for Teachers: Geometry
description: Geometry. May be repeated to a maximum of 3 hours so long as no topic is repeated. May not count toward a concentration or minor in mathematics. Requires consent of instructor.

title: Mathematics Topics for Teachers: History of Mathematics
description: History of Mathematics. May be repeated to a maximum of 3 hours so long as no topic is repeated. May not count toward a concentration or minor in mathematics. Requires consent of instructor.

title: Mathematics Topics for Teachers: Applied Mathematics
description: Applied mathematics. May be repeated to a maximum of 3 hours so long as no topic is repeated. May not count toward a concentration or minor in mathematics. Requires consent of instructor.

title: Mathematics Topics for Teachers: Logic & Foundations
description: Logic and foundations. May be repeated to a maximum of 3 hours so long as no topic is repeated. May not count toward a concentration or minor in mathematics. Requires consent of instructor.

title: Abstract Algebra
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 320 Minimum Grade of C
description: Rings, fields, integral domains, homomorphisms, factor rings, rings of polynomials, prime ideals, maximal ideals, extension fields, and vector spaces.

title: Linear Algebra II
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 223 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 250 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 321 Minimum Grade of C
description: Advanced study of vector spaces: Cayley-Hamilton Theorem, minimal and characteristic polynomials, Eigen spaces, canonical forms, Lagrange-Sylvester Theorem, and applications.

title: Combinatorics and Graph Theory
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 223
description: Methods of solving problems which are discrete in nature. Counting combinatorial reasoning and modeling; generating functions; and recurrence relations. Graphs: definitions, examples, basic properties, applications, and algorithms. Some knowledge of programming is recommended.

title: A Geometric Introduction to Topology
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 350 Minimum Grade of C AND
description: Topological spaces and equivalence through the study of knots, links, surfaces, 3-manifolds and other selected topics.

title: Foundations for Euclidean & Non-Euclidean Geometry
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 250 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 321 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 320 Minimum Grade of C OR MATH 350 Minimum Grade of C
description: Points; lines; planes; space; separations; congruence; parallelism and similarity; non-Euclidean geometries; and independence of the parallel axiom. Riemannian and Bolyai-Lobachevskian geometries.

title: Differential Geometry
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 250 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 321 Minimum Grade of C
description: Curves and surfaces in Euclidean 3-space from the perspective of classical differential geometry. Topics include: Frenet frames, fundamental surface forms, geodesics, and the Gauss-Bonnet theorem.

title: Real Analysis I
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 350 Minimum Grade of C
description: Integration; infinite series, sequences and series of functions and their properties.

title: Introduction to Complex Analysis
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 350 Minimum Grade of C
description: Analytic functions, Cauchy-Riemann equations, harmonic functions, elements of conformal mapping, line integrals, Cauchy-Goursat theorem, Cauchy integral formula, power series, the residue theorem and applications.

title: Applied Numerical Analysis
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 250 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 305 Minimum Grade of C AND (CS 140 Minimum Grade of C OR CS 145 Minimum Grade of C OR MATH 165 Minimum Grade of C)
description: Polynomial interpolation and approximations; numerical integration; differentiation; and direct and iterative methods for linear systems. Numerical solutions for ODE's and PDE's. Matlab programming required.

title: Partial Differential Equations
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 223 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 250 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 305 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 321 Minimum Grade of C
description: Partial differential equations, heat equation, wave equation, Laplace’s equation, Fourier series, Fourier transform, method of separations of variable.

title: Topics in Mathematics
description: 490a-h, 1-3 each Topics in Mathematic — Selected topics in specified area of interest. (a) Algebra, (b) Geometry and topology, (c) Analysis, (d) Mathematics education, (e) Logic and foundations, (f) Differential equations, (g) Numerical analysis, (h) Combinatorics and graph theory. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours so long as no topic is repeated. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

title: Topics in Mathematics
description: 490a-h, 1-3 each Topics in Mathematic — Selected topics in specified area of interest. (a) Algebra, (b) Geometry and topology, (c) Analysis, (d) Mathematics education, (e) Logic and foundations, (f) Differential equations, (g) Numerical analysis, (h) Combinatorics and graph theory. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours so long as no topic is repeated. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

title: Topics in Mathematics
description: 490a-h, 1-3 each Topics in Mathematic — Selected topics in specified area of interest. (a) Algebra, (b) Geometry and topology, (c) Analysis, (d) Mathematics education, (e) Logic and foundations, (f) Differential equations, (g) Numerical analysis, (h) Combinatorics and graph theory. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours so long as no topic is repeated. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

description: 490a-h, 1-3 each Topics in Mathematic — Selected topics in specified area of interest. (a) Algebra, (b) Geometry and topology, (c) Analysis, (d) Mathematics education, (e) Logic and foundations, (f) Differential equations, (g) Numerical analysis, (h) Combinatorics and graph theory. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours so long as no topic is repeated. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

description: 490a-h, 1-3 each Topics in Mathematic — Selected topics in specified area of interest. (a) Algebra, (b) Geometry and topology, (c) Analysis, (d) Mathematics education, (e) Logic and foundations, (f) Differential equations, (g) Numerical analysis, (h) Combinatorics and graph theory. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours so long as no topic is repeated. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

title: Topics in Mathematics
description: 490a-h, 1-3 each Topics in Mathematic — Selected topics in specified area of interest. (a) Algebra, (b) Geometry and topology, (c) Analysis, (d) Mathematics education, (e) Logic and foundations, (f) Differential equations, (g) Numerical analysis, (h) Combinatorics and graph theory. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours so long as no topic is repeated. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

title: Topics in Mathematics
description: 490a-h, 1-3 each Topics in Mathematic — Selected topics in specified area of interest. (a) Algebra, (b) Geometry and topology, (c) Analysis, (d) Mathematics education, (e) Logic and foundations, (f) Differential equations, (g) Numerical analysis, (h) Combinatorics and graph theory. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours so long as no topic is repeated. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

title: Topics in Mathematics
description: 490a-h, 1-3 each Topics in Mathematic — Selected topics in specified area of interest. (a) Algebra, (b) Geometry and topology, (c) Analysis, (d) Mathematics education, (e) Logic and foundations, (f) Differential equations, (g) Numerical analysis, (h) Combinatorics and graph theory. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours so long as no topic is repeated. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

title: Independent Study: Algebra
description: Research and reading in specified area of interest. Algebra. May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours so long as no topic is repeated and not more than 3 hours are accumulated in neither a single segment nor more than 6 in one semester. Requires written consent of adviser and instructor.

title: Independent Study: Geometry
description: Research and reading in specified area of interest. Geometry. May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours so long as no topic is repeated and not more than 3 hours are accumulated in neither a single segment nor more than 6 in one semester. Requires written consent of adviser and instructor.

title: Independent Study: Analysis
description: Research and reading in specified area of interest. Analysis. May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours so long as no topic is repeated and not more than 3 hours are accumulated in neither a single segment nor more than 6 in one semester. Requires written consent of adviser and instructor.

title: Independent Study: Mathematics Education
description: Research and reading in specified area of interest. Mathematics education. May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours so long as no topic is repeated and not more than 3 hours are accumulated in neither a single segment nor more than 6 in one semester. Requires written consent of adviser.

title: Independent Study: Logic & Foundations
description: Research and reading in specified area of interest. Logic & foundations. May be repeated to a max of 9 hours so long as no topic is repeated and not more than 3 hours are accumulated in neither a single segment nor more than 6 in one semester. Requires written consent of adviser and instructor.

title: Independent Study: Topology
description: Research and reading in specified area of interest. Topology. May be repeated to a maximum of 9 hours so long as no topic is repeated and not more than 3 hours are accumulated in neither a single segment nor more than 6 in one semester. Requires written consent of adviser and instructor.

title: Independent Study: Numerical Analysis
description: Research and reading in specified area of interest. Numerical analysis. May be repeated to a max of 9 hours so long as no topic is repeated and not more than 3 hours are accumulated in neither a single segment nor more than 6 in one semester. Requires written consent of adviser and instructor.

title: Senior Seminar
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 150 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 152 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 250 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 223 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 321 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 350 Minimum Grade of C AND (CS 140 Minimum Grade of C OR CS 145 Minimum Grade of C) AND (PHYS 211A Minimum Grade of C OR PHYS 151 Minimum Grade of C) AND (PHYS 212A Minimum Grade of C OR PHYS 151L Minimum Grade of C)
description: Mathematical modeling. The writing and presenting of mathematical ideas. Preparation for senior project.

title: Senior Project
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 498 Minimum Grade of C
description: Directed study toward completing the senior assignment. Student completes a written project and gives an oral presentation.

title: Statistics
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 120 Minimum Grade of C OR MATH 120E Minimum Grade of C OR MATH 120I Minimum Grade of C OR MATH 125 Minimum Grade of C OR MATH 145 Minimum Grade of C OR MATH 150 Minimum Grade of C
description: Summarizing data, including distributions, change and growth, relationships. Basics of survey design and experimental design. Inferential statistics, including confidence intervals and hypothesis testing. Credit may not be granted for both STAT 107 and STAT 244. IAI Course M1 902.

title: Statistics For Applications
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 152 Minimum Grade of C AND
description: Descriptive statistics; basic probability rules and distributions; inferences for means; variances and proportions; design and analysis of experiments; and regression analysis.

title: Concepts of Physics
prerequisitesRaw: AD 095 Minimum Grade of C AND AD 085 Minimum Grade of C
description: Introduction to our understanding of the universe and how it is achieved. Includes selections from: Motion, energy, heat, fluids, electricity, magnetism, sound, light, atoms. IAI Course P1 900.

title: Conceptual Physics Laboratory
prerequisitesRaw: PHYS 111 (concurrency allowed)
description: Weekly introductory laboratory dealing with mechanics, heat, electricity, sound and light. Emphasis placed on measurements and data analysis.

title: Energy and the Environment
description: Problems and prospects of meeting national and worldwide energy demands. Scientific background, role, and environmental impact of fossil fuel, nuclear, solar, geothermal, and other technologies. IAI Course P1 901.

title: Music and Acoustics
description: Vibrations; nature and propagation of sound waves; musical pitch and intervals; tone quality, analysis, and synthesis; instruments; speech; ears and hearing; psychological aspects; and other topics. IAI Course P1 901.

title: Light and Color
description: Nature of light; ray and wave phenomena; optical devices; the eye; color theory; lasers and holography; applications to art, photography, and other visual media. IAI Course P1 901.

title: Astronomy
description: Introduction to observation; seasons; light; telescopes; orbits; solar system; stellar structure, evolution and classification; galaxies and cosmology. Includes in-class activities and supplemental viewing sessions. IAI Course P1 906.

title: Astronomy Laboratory
description: An experiential laboratory course utilizing both software and real-time observation concerning astronomical objects.

title: Frontiers in Physics: Past and Present
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 125 Minimum Grade of C
description: Introductory course designed to highlight, through examples, how progress and discoveries are made in physics. Topics selected from historical and/or contemporary physics. May include seminar.

title: College Physics I: Mechanics and Heat
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 125 OR MATH 145 OR MATH 150 OR MATH 152
description: This course is the first semester of a two semester sequence. Designed to meet pre-medical and biological science requirements. Topics include mechanics, fluids, energy and heat and gravitation.

title: College Physics I Laboratory: Mechanics and Heat
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 125 OR MATH 145 OR MATH 150 OR MATH 152
description: This course is a laboratory for College Physics I. Topics include physical measurements, data analysis, lab reporting and error analysis.

title: College Physics II: Electricity, Magnetism and Optics
prerequisitesRaw: PHYS 131
description: This course is the second semester of a two semester sequence. Designed to meet pre-medical and biological science requirements. Topics include waves and sound, electrostatics, circuits magnetism, EM waves, optics and modern physics theory.

title: College Physics II Laboratory: Electricity, Magnetism and Optics
prerequisitesRaw: PHYS 131L
description: A lab consisting of experiments designed to complement PHYS 132: physical measurements, data analysis, presentation and error analysis.

title: Introduction to Physics and Physical Reasoning
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 150 Minimum Grade of C (concurrency allowed)
description: An introduction to physics and quantitative reasoning preparatory for PHYS 141/151. Selected physics concepts, methods of reasoning, application of mathematics to physics problem solving.

title: Physics I for Engineers
prerequisitesRaw: (MATH 152 Minimum Grade of C (concurrency allowed) OR MATH 250 Minimum Grade of C (concurrency allowed)) AND (ACT Math 28 OR Physics Readiness Exam Score 09 OR MATH TEST SCORE 32.5 OR PHYS 140 Minimum Grade of C)
description: Introductory calculus-based course for engineering students: Motion, kinematics, dynamics, Newton's Laws, applications; work; kinetic & potential energy, momentum; rotational dynamics, angular momentum; gravity; oscillations.

title: Physics II for Engineering
prerequisitesRaw: (PHYS 141 Minimum Grade of C OR PHYS 151 Minimum Grade of C) AND MATH 152 Minimum Grade of C AND PHYS 151L Minimum Grade of C
description: Calculus-based course for engineering students: electric charge, electric fields, Gauss' law, electric potential; magnetic fields, Faraday's Law, inductance, Maxwell's equations integral form; electromagnetic waves.

title: University Physics I
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 152 Minimum Grade of C (concurrency allowed)
description: Kinematics; dynamics; planar motion; work and energy; momentum; rotational motion; gravitation; and fluids. IAI Course P2 900.

title: University Physics I Laboratory
prerequisitesRaw: PHYS 151 Minimum Grade of C (concurrency allowed) OR PHYS 141 Minimum Grade of C (concurrency allowed) OR PHYS 211A Minimum Grade of C
description: Physics measurements; data analysis and presentation, error analysis. Velocity; acceleration; force and moments; work and kinetic energy. IAI Course P2 900L.

title: University Physics II
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 152 Minimum Grade of C AND (PHYS 151 Minimum Grade of C OR PHYS 141 Minimum Grade of C)
description: Bulk properties of matter; oscillations and waves; electric charge; electric fields; Gauss' law; potentials; circuits; magnetic fields; and electromagnetic waves.

title: University Physics II Lab
description: Physics measurements; data analysis and presentation; error analysis; thermal and bulk properties of matter; simple harmonic motion and waves; electromagnetism; simple circuits; and optics.

title: Freshman Project in Biomedical Physics
description: With guidance, a freshman investigatory or independent study project in bio- or biomedical physics. Open to all students of other disciplines and to 100-level physics students.

title: Freshman Project in Photonics and Laser Physics
description: With guidance, a freshman investigatory or independent study project in photonics. Open to all students of other disciplines and to 100-level physics students.

title: Freshman Project in Astronomy
description: With guidance, a freshman investigatory or independent project in astronomy. Open to all students of other disciplines and to 100-level physics students.

title: Freshman Project in Experimental Physics
description: With guidance, a freshman investigatory or independent study project in experimental physics. Open to all students of other disciplines and to 100-level physics students.

title: Freshman Project in Theoretical Physics
description: With guidance, a freshman investigatory or independent study project in theoretical physics. Open to all students of other disciplines and to 100-level physics students.

title: University Physics III
prerequisitesRaw: (PHYS 151 Minimum Grade of C OR PHYS 211A Minimum Grade of C) AND (PHYS 152 Minimum Grade of C OR PHYS 211B Minimum Grade of C)
description: Electromagnetic waves. Physical optics: interference and diffraction. Introductory special relativity; thermodynamic laws; Maxwell Boltzmann distributions; equipartition theorem; black-body radiation; and evidence for photons. Bohr atom and matter waves.

title: University Physics III Laboratory
description: Laboratories covering select topics from Electromagnetic waves, physical optics, introductory special relativity, thermodynamic laws, and introductory quantum physics.

title: Introduction to Chemistry
prerequisitesRaw: ALEKS PPL - Math Plcmnt 30
description: Preparation for University Chemistry. Mathematical techniques, problem solving, chemical terms, concepts, and laws. For students with inadequate preparation in high school chemistry. Three lecture hours and one problem session per week.

title: General, Organic, and Biological Chemistry
description: Not for Chemistry majors. General chemistry. Three lecture hours and one laboratory per week. Must be taken in sequence. IAI Course P1 902.

title: General, Organic, and Biological Chemistry
prerequisitesRaw: CHEM 120A
description: Primarily for students planning careers in Nursing and Allied Health professions. Not for Chemistry majors. Organic and biological Chemistry. Three lecture hours and one laboratory per week. Must be taken in sequence.

title: General Chemistry
prerequisitesRaw: (MATH 120 Minimum Grade of C OR MATH 120E Minimum Grade of C OR MATH 120I Minimum Grade of C AND CHEM 113 Minimum Grade of C) OR MATH 125 Minimum Grade of C (concurrency allowed) OR MATH 145 Minimum Grade of C (concurrency allowed) OR MATH 150 Minimum Grade of C (concurrency allowed) OR ALEKS PPL - Math Plcmnt 61 OR Chemistry Readiness Exam Score 39 OR (Chemistry Readiness Exam Score 34 AND CRE General Math Subscore 17)
description: University-level modern chemistry for science and engineering students, atomic structure, molecular bonding, structure, stoichiometry, chemical change, equilibrium, and qualitative analysis. Four lecture hours per week. Must be taken in sequence. IAI Course P1 902, CHM 911.

title: General Chemistry
prerequisitesRaw: CHEM 121A Minimum Grade of C
description: University-level modern chemistry for science and engineering students. Atomic structure, molecular bonding, structure, stoichiometry, chemical change, equilibrium, and qualitative analysis. Four lecture hours per week. Must be taken in sequence. IAI Course CHM 912.

title: General, Organic, and Biological Chemistry Laboratory
description: Safety practices and basic techniques. Topics complement CHEM 120. Not for Chemistry majors. General and organic Chemistry. Three laboratory hours per week. Must be taken in sequence. This course replaces CHEM 120A-Lab portion. IAI Course P1 902L.

title: General, Organic, and Biological Chemistry Laboratory
prerequisitesRaw: CHEM 124A
description: Safety practices and basic techniques. Topics complement CHEM 120. Not for Chemistry majors. (A)General and Organic Chemistry. Three laboratory hours per week. Must be taken in sequence. Replaces CHEM 120B-Lab portion.

title: General Chemistry Lab
description: Laboratory safety practices and techniques; qualitative and quantitative analysis; chemical change and equilibria. One three-hour laboratory per week. IAI Course P1 902L, CHM 911.

title: General Chemistry Laboratory
description: Laboratory safety practices, techniques, qualitative and quantitative analysis, chemical change and equilibria. One - three hour laboratory per week. IAI Course CHM 912.

title: Engineering Chemistry
prerequisitesRaw: (MATH 120 Minimum Grade of C OR MATH 120E Minimum Grade of C OR MATH 120I Minimum Grade of C AND CHEM 113 Minimum Grade of C) OR MATH 125 Minimum Grade of C (concurrency allowed) OR MATH 145 Minimum Grade of C (concurrency allowed) OR MATH 150 Minimum Grade of C (concurrency allowed) OR ALEKS PPL - Math Plcmnt 61 OR Chemistry Readiness Exam Score 39 OR (Chemistry Readiness Exam Score 34 AND CRE General Math Subscore 17)
description: Fundamental principles of chemistry especially for students planning careers in engineering fields. Concepts represent the basic principles of chemistry with emphasis on engineering applications.

title: Engineering Chemistry Lab
description: Chemical laboratory experiments with an emphasis on engineering applications. Laboratory safety practices, techniques, qualitative and quantitative analysis, chemical change and equilibria. One three-hour laboratory per week.

title: Contemporary Biology
description: Contributions of biology to understanding ourselves and our world. Development, nature and human implications of cell theory, heredity, the modern synthetic theory of evolution, population dynamics, ecology and environmental problems. Not for biological sciences major credit. IAI Course L1 900.

title: Human Biology
description: Introduction and application of basic human biology concepts, including cell theory, genetics, systems biology, and evolution. Not for biological sciences major credit. Three lectures per week. IAI Course L1 904.

title: Fundamentals of Biology
description: Introduction to basic biology concepts, including cell theory, genetics, systems biology, and evolution. Lab required. Not for biological sciences major credit.

title: Introduction to Biological Sciences I
prerequisitesRaw: CHEM 121A Minimum Grade of C (concurrency allowed)
description: First of a two-course sequence, introduction to biochemistry, molecular genetics, cell structure and function, and evolution. Lab required. IAI Course BIO LI 900L, BIOL 910.

title: Introduction to Biological Sciences II
prerequisitesRaw: BIOL 150 Minimum Grade of C AND CHEM 121A Minimum Grade of C AND CHEM 125A Minimum Grade of C
description: Second of a two-course sequence, introduction to major taxonomic groups with emphasis on evolutionary relationships and ecological principles. Lab required. IAI Course BIO 910.

title: Human Anatomy & Physiology
prerequisitesRaw: (BIOL 140 Minimum Grade of C OR BIOL 150 Minimum Grade of C OR BIOL 151 Minimum Grade of C) AND (CHEM 120A Minimum Grade of C OR CHEM 120N Minimum Grade of C OR CHEM 121A Minimum Grade of C)
description: Functional architecture of the human body. Tissues, skeletal, muscular and nervous systems. Not for major credit.

title: Human Anatomy & Physiology
prerequisitesRaw: BIOL 240A Minimum Grade of C
description: Continuation of BIOL240A. Endocrine, Circulatory, Respiratory, Digestive, Urinary systems. Not for major credit.

title: Introduction to Computer Programming
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 120 Minimum Grade of C OR MATH 120E Minimum Grade of C
description: Specification, design, implementation, testing, debugging, applications in numerical analysis and computer simulations. Control structures, functions, arrays and other data types. Programming in C, Python, and Matlab.

title: Electrical and Computer Engineering Work Experience I
description: Supervised work experience with agency, firm, or organization which uses engineers. Intended for students who have part-time cooperative experience jobs. Limited to students enrolled in more than 6 credit hours. Student must be a declared major in electrical and computer engineering.

title: Electrical and Computer Engineering Cooperative Education I
description: Supervised work experience with agency, firm, or organization which uses engineers. First work period of five year academic/work experience program. Requires consent of advisor.

title: Circuit Analysis I
prerequisitesRaw: MATH 150 Minimum Grade of C
description: DC and AC steady-state circuit analysis. Loop and nodal analysis; network theorems; phasors; complex power; and single-phase and three-phase circuits. IAI Course EGR 931.

title: Circuit Analysis II
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 210 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 305 Minimum Grade of C (concurrency allowed) AND MATH 150 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 152 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 250 Minimum Grade of C
description: Time-domain transient analysis; complex frequency; frequency response; two-port networks; Laplace transform techniques; and impulse response and convolution. Three hours lecture and one laboratory session per week.

title: Digital Systems Design
prerequisitesRaw: CS 140 Minimum Grade of C OR CS 145 Minimum Grade of C
description: Concepts and design of computer circuitry; binary number systems; study of microprocessors and assembly language programming. Introduction to Verilog HDL. Laboratory exercises involve circuit implementation and programming. Three lecture hours and one laboratory session per week. Student must be a declared major in an engineering discipline. IAI Course EGR 932L.

title: Electrical and Computer Engineering Work Experience II
description: Supervised work experience with agency, firm, or organization which uses engineers. Intended for students who have part-time cooperative experience jobs. Limited to students enrolled in more than 6 credit hours.

title: ECE Cooperative Education II
description: Supervised work experience with agency, firm, or organization which uses engineers. Second work period of five year academic/work experience program. Requires consent of advisor.

title: Electronic Circuits I
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 211 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 305 Minimum Grade of C
description: Introduction to semiconductors; diode, transistor and FET; small and large signal analysis; and logic gate families and design. Three hours lecture and one laboratory session per week. Student must be a declared major in an engineering discipline.

title: Engineering Electromagnetics
prerequisitesRaw: (PHYS 152 Minimum Grade of C OR PHYS 211B Minimum Grade of C) AND (PHYS 152L Minimum Grade of C OR PHYS 212B Minimum Grade of C) AND ECE 211 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 305 Minimum Grade of C
description: Introduction to engineering electromagnetics. Includes vector analysis, time-harmonic fields, electromagnetic wave propagation, transmission lines, waveguides, antennas.

title: Princ w/Electro Mec Enrg Conv
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 340 Minimum Grade of C
description: Basic electromagnetic concepts; energy-based torque and force and calculations; transformers; induction machines; synchronous machines; and DC machines. Three hours lecture and one laboratory session per week.

title: Signals and Systems
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 211 Minimum Grade of C AND MATH 305 Minimum Grade of C
description: Basics of continuous and discrete signals and systems. Convolution; Fourier analysis; filtering; modulation and sampling; and Z-transforms. Student must be a declared major in an engineering discipline.

title: Engineering Probability and Statistics
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 351 Minimum Grade of C (concurrency allowed)
description: Probability; random variables and probability distributions; statistics; Monte-Carlo simulations; estimation theory; decision theory; hypothesis testing; random processes; and linear system response to random processes.

title: Control Systems
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 351 Minimum Grade of C
description: Mechanical and electrical systems modeling, signal flow graphs, state variable approach, root-locus approach, Bode ploys/Nyquist plots, frequency domain design and Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) controller turning methods.

title: Introduction to Communications
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 351 Minimum Grade of C AND ECE 352 Minimum Grade of C
description: Time- and frequency-domain analysis; and bandwidth, distortion, and noise. Baseband pulse transmission; sampling; pulse shaping. Digital and analog modulation techniques. Analysis of bit-error probability.

title: Microcontrollers
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 282 Minimum Grade of C
description: Interfacing and programming microcontrollers to measure/control various hardware and signals, GPIO, LCD, ISRs, encoders, UART/RS-232, I2C, SPI, ADC/DAC. Three hours lecture and one laboratory session per week.

title: Electrical and Computer Engineering Work Experience III
description: Supervised work experience with agency, firm, or organization which uses engineers. Intended for students who have part-time cooperative experience jobs. Limited to students enrolled in more than 6 credit hours.

title: ECE Cooperative Education III
description: Supervised work experience with agency, firm, or organization which uses engineers. Third work period of five year academic/work experience program. Requires consent of advisor.

title: Electrical and Computer Engineering Design
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 282 Minimum Grade of C AND ECE 351 Minimum Grade of C AND (ECE 365 Minimum Grade of C OR ECE 375 Minimum Grade of C OR ECE 381 Minimum Grade of C)
description: Design overview, methodologies, considerations, constraints, scheduling, and management. Focus on both oral and written communication. Students work in teams while rotating leadership responsibilities.

title: Electrical and Computer Engineering Design Laboratory
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 404 Minimum Grade of C
description: Realization of a term-based senior project, including construction, computer simulation, debug, and test as required by the project to obtain a functional prototype.

title: High Frequency Design
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 326 Minimum Grade of C
description: High frequency circuit design with elements of RF engineering. Amplifiers, oscillators, modulators, impedance matching, switching, signal integrity, and tuning.

title: Knowledge-Based Systems
prerequisitesRaw: CS 140 Minimum Grade of C OR CS 145 Minimum Grade of C
description: Engineering-oriented perspective on artificial intelligence (AI) technology. General AI concepts and specifically knowledge-based intelligent systems and machine learning applied to engineering problem-solving.

title: Analog Filter Design
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 351 Minimum Grade of C AND ECE 326 Minimum Grade of C
description: Active and passive filter synthesis. Standard low-pass approximations: Butterworth, Chebyshev, Inverse Chebyshev, Cauer, Bessel and frequency transformations. Active and passive circuit implementations.

title: Bioinstrumentation
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 327 with a C or better; or graduate standing in Engineering.
description: Design and use of biosignal sensors, bioamplifiers, and filters for measuring physiological data; emphasizes origins and characteristics of nerve and heart signals; includes cell analysis and dialysis machine design.

title: Fuzzy Logic and Applications
description: Fundamentals of fuzzy sets, basic operations, fuzzy arithmetic, and fuzzy systems. Examples of applications in various fields of engineering and science.

title: Digital Signal Processing
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 351 Minimum Grade of C
description: Discrete-time signals and systems; sampling; z-transforms; discrete Fourier transform; difference equations; design and implementation of digital filters; and DSP development systems.

title: Medical Imaging Systems
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 351 Minimum Grade of C
description: Basic signals and systems, imaging principles, and image quality measures for X-ray radiography, X-ray computed tomography, ultrasound, and magnetic resonance imaging.

title: Image Analysis and Computer Vision
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 351 Minimum Grade of C
description: Image formation, geometrical and topological properties of binary images; image filtering; boundary detection; image segmentation; and pattern recognition. Two hours lecture and one laboratory session per week.

title: Digital Image Processing
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 351 Minimum Grade of C
description: Fundamentals of human perception; sampling and quantization; image transforms; enhancement; and restoration and coding. Two hours lecture and one laboratory session per week.

title: Finite Element Analysis and Design of Electrical Machines
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 341 or equivalent courses with C or better or admission to graduate ENGE program.
description: Practical design of electrical machines based on finite element analysis.

title: Power Electronics
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 326 with C or better or admission to graduate Engineering Program.
description: Basics of DC/DC and DC/AC conversion, inductors, transformers, switching characteristics of semiconductor devices, elements of electromagnetic compatibility.

title: Power Distribution System
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 341 Minimum Grade of C
description: Distribution system planning; load characteristics; application of distribution transformers; design of distribution system; voltage-drop and power-loss calculations; voltage regulation; and protection and reliability.

title: Power System Analysis
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 341 Minimum Grade of C
description: Synchronous machines; power transformers; transmission lines; system modeling; load-flow study; economic operation of power systems; symmetrical components; symmetrical and unsymmetrical faults; and power system stability.

title: Radar Systems
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 340 Minimum Grade of C AND ECE 351 Minimum Grade of C
description: Introduction to radar systems, including antenna fundamentals, radar equation, radar signals and systems, CW radar, FM-CW Radar, pulse radar, and tracking radar.

title: System Modeling & Optimization
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 351 Minimum Grade of C
description: Mathematical modeling of engineering systems; dynamic response of electrical and mechanical systems; and optimization models in electrical engineering.

title: Control Systems Design
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 365 Minimum Grade of C
description: Root-locus analysis; frequency-response analysis; design and compensation technique; describing-function analysis of nonlinear control systems; and analysis and design by state-space methods.

title: Digital Control
prerequisitesRaw: ME 450 Minimum Grade of C OR ECE 365 Minimum Grade of C
description: Topics include finite difference equations; Z-transforms and state variable representation; analysis and synthesis of linear sampled-data control systems using classical and modern control theory. Same as ME 466.

title: Robotics-Dynamics and Control
description: (Same as ME 454 and MRE 454) Robotics; robot kinematics and inverse kinematics; trajectory planning; differential motion and virtual work principle; and dynamics and control.

title: Communication Systems
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 375 Minimum Grade of C
description: Digital transmission through band-limited channels; optimum receiver principles; symbol synchronization; channel capacity and coding; Bandpass digital modulation; and case studies of communication systems.

title: Electronic Circuits II
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 326 Minimum Grade of C
description: Small signal analysis, transistor amplifier design, frequency response, feedback system analysis, output stage design, signal generation and waveform shaping circuits. Three hour lecture and one hour laboratory session per week.

title: Network Engineering
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 282 Minimum Grade of C
description: Principles and practices of network engineering with particular emphasis on the physical, data-link, and network layers as applied to telecommunication and computing systems.

title: Microprocessor System
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 282 Minimum Grade of C
description: Design of microprocessor systems using VLSI building blocks. Several microprocessors and peripheral ICS studied laboratory experiments with microprocessor systems using logic analyzers. Three hours lecture and one laboratory session per week.

title: Advanced Digital Systems Engineering
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 282 Minimum Grade of C
description: Design of digital systems using a hardware description language, and logic synthesis tools. Three hours lecture and one laboratory session per week.

title: Digital VLSI Design
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 326 Minimum Grade of C
description: Discussion of CMOS circuits, MOS transistor theory, CMOS processing technology, circuit characterization, and CMOS Circuit and Logic Design.

title: Embedded Power Electronics Controllers
prerequisitesRaw: ECE 282 Minimum Grade of C
description: Practical approach to programming dedicated microprocessor systems, communication links, sensor signal conditioning, gate driver, inner and outer control loops, power startup, and user interface.

title: Independent Study
description: Individual investigation of a topic in electrical engineering to be agreed upon with the instructor. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours provided no topic is repeated. Requires consent of instructor.

title: Topics in Electrical and Computer Engineering
description: Selected topics of special interest. Course schedule will include name of topic. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours so long as no topic is repeated. Requires consent of instructor.

title: Personal Health
description: This seminar will introduce students to basic concepts in personal health and wellness.

title: Sexual Health
description: Surveys the dynamics of sexual health as related to overall health. Identifies and examines basic issues in human sexuality as relating to larger society.

title: Violence and Injury Prevention
description: Provides a broad understanding of violence and injury as a public health issue. Stresses importance of prevention initiatives, environmental modifications, legal interventions, and advocacy.

title: Drug Use and Abuse
description: Drug and non-drug alternatives that modify mood and behavior; factors influencing use, effects, and legal control; students' personal values, motivations and choices concerning drug use.

title: Emotional Health and Stress Management
description: An introduction to a variety of types of positive and negative emotions and their determinants in addition to their contributions to an individual's overall well-being.

title: Introduction to Applied Nutrition
description: Primary roles of major nutrients in human body functions. Relationships between these nutrients and health outcomes/conditions including diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, cancer, osteoporosis and obesity.

title: Women's Health
description: Explores health trends that affect women. Analysis of psychosocial influences on health with particular emphasis on the link between wealth and health. Same as WMST 300.

title: Foundations of Community and Public Health
description: Introduces the history, philosophy, core disciplines of public health, including health education; describes the major public health threats and future directions of public health

title: Public Health Data Analysis
prerequisitesRaw: STAT 107 Minimum Grade of C OR STAT 244 Minimum Grade of C
description: Basic concepts of biostatistics, descriptive and inferential statistics and their interpretation and application in resolving real-world public health issues, and hands-on practice of statistic software.

title: Public Health Policy and Management
prerequisitesRaw: HED 111 OR PBHE 111
description: Review, analyze, and formulate a public health related policy. A model for an individual, community, and society to make informed consumer health related decisions.

title: Public Health Communication
prerequisitesRaw: HED 305 Minimum Grade of C OR PBHE 305 Minimum Grade of C (concurrency allowed)
description: Effective public health communication strategies for internal and external individuals, groups, and organizations to respond to health information, misinformation, and disinformation.

title: Research Methods in Health
description: General concepts and foundations of measurement, evaluation, and research; major methods and techniques of research and evaluation. Special emphasis given to conducting small research assignments.

title: Health Coaching
prerequisitesRaw: HED 305 OR PBHE 305
description: Theories of health behavior and behavior change. Exploration of helping role as it relates to health behavior, health assessment analysis, decision making, problem solving, and referral skills.

title: Environment Health
prerequisitesRaw: HED 111 OR PBHE 111 OR HED 201 OR PBHE 201
description: People's relationship with their environment; impact relationship has on status of one's health; and individual and community roles in promotion of environmental health. Not for graduate credit.

title: Contemporary and Controversial Issues in Health
prerequisitesRaw: HED 305 OR PBHE 305
description: Investigation of current controversial issues in health and health care. Emphasis on critical analysis and presentation of complex challenges from a public health perspective.

title: Introduction to Epidemiology
prerequisitesRaw: PBHE 353 Minimum Grade of C
description: Epidemiologic terminologies. Description and analysis of disease occurrence using appropriate epidemiologic measurements. Exploration of causal relationships. Identification of epidemiologic roles in disease control and prevention.

title: Special Topics in Public Health
description: Relevant health issues. Topic and credit hours announced. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours so long as no topic is repeated.

title: Independent Study in Public Health
description: Independent projects or readings under the supervision of a public health faculty member.

title: Program Planning in Community Health
prerequisitesRaw: (HED 370 OR PBHE 370) AND (HED 375 OR PBHE 375) AND PBHE 305 Minimum Grade of C
description: Principles and approaches of planning programs within the community. Examination of program planning models. Application to various health education settings.

title: Program Implementation and Evaluation in Community Health
prerequisitesRaw: PBHE 490 Minimum Grade of C
description: Principles and practices of health education program implementation and evaluation. Application of selected models and assessment strategies of community health education.

title: Grant Writing in Public Health
prerequisitesRaw: PBHE 490 Minimum Grade of C
description: Practical application in the development of a grant for a public health agency or community. Strategies for exploring funding, collaboration, and preparation of quality proposals.

title: Senior Professional Seminar
prerequisitesRaw: (HED 491 (concurrency allowed) OR PBHE 491 (concurrency allowed))
description: Discussion of topics related to health education; ethics, professional responsibilities, preparation, and certification and future trends. Completion of portfolio and senior assignment required.

title: Internship in Public Health
prerequisitesRaw: HED 498 (concurrency allowed) OR PBHE 498 (concurrency allowed)
description: Supervised experiences in health agencies, clinics, government agencies and other professional settings. Not for graduate credit.

title: Conflict Management and Communication
description: The study and practice of effective conflict management techniques including mediation, negotiation, and active listening strategies. Highlights the interdependence between communication, conflict, and professional growth.

title: Intercultural Communication
description: This course examines the processes, assumptions and barriers in intercultural encounters. Theories of cognition and communication will be explored.

title: Health Communication
description: Examines the role of communication and culture in general models of health and illness, caregiver-patient relationships, social support, and health campaigns.

title: Medical Anthropology
description: Theories and applications of medical anthropology. Cross-cultural perspectives on health and medicine.

title: Human Variation
description: Examines differences between biological and social perspectives on human variation. Includes ethics, methods, and theory regarding variation in human genetics, sex, intelligence, health, and behavior.

title: Perspectives on Terrorism
description: A survey of international and domestic terrorism, the organizations, philosophies, and responses. Investigates the social, psychological, cultural, historical, political, religious, and economic dynamics of terrorism.

title: United States Drug Policy
description: Examine historical and contemporary drug use and policy efforts, including secondary problems affiliated with drugs; and the war on drugs and its impact nationally and internationally.

title: Mental Health and the Criminal Justice System
description: Explores treatment of individuals with mental illness by police, courts, and corrections. Insanity defense, competency, commitment, diversion, and CIT discussed.

title: Human Geography
description: Geographic principles underlying the location and distribution of people and their activities in relation to the environment. IAI Course S4 900N.

title: Medical Geography
prerequisitesRaw: GEOG 205 Minimum Grade of C
description: This course examines medical geographic principles to understand the diversity of health around the world and the processes connecting them.

title: Geographic Information Systems (GIS)
description: Concepts, basic theory, and principles of GIS using both Raster and Vector data models in a PC environment.

title: Topcs in Geographic Techniques
description: Specific topics in geographic techniques based on faculty expertise. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.

title: Medical Terminology
description: Learn to read and comprehend original research, medical reports, and health/fitness evaluations related to prefixes, suffixes, and word roots of medical terms.

title: Fundamentals of Advertising
description: Provides an overview of advertising from the perspectives of marketing and social roles of advertising, consumer behavior, media, strategic research and planning, creative, and IMC.

title: New Media and Technology
description: Technological changes in the mass media. New media forms; audience fragmentation; and economic, regulatory, and social issues. Patters of adoption and diffusion.

title: Mass Media and Health
description: Focuses on media literacy in the area of health, ethics related to media health content, the influence media have on health behavior and health policy.

title: Human Development Across the Lifespan
prerequisitesRaw: PSYC 111
description: Human growth and development and variations from conception to old age. Includes development of physiological, psychological, sociocultural, moral, ethical and spiritual systems. Non-majors can enroll with advisor permission.

title: Introduction to Human Nutrition
description: Fundamental principles of nutrition, including the role of specific nutrients, digestion, absorption, and metabolism. Application of concepts as they relate to humans across the lifespan will be discussed.

title: Community Nutrition
prerequisitesRaw: NUTR 250 Minimum Grade of C
description: Assessment, planning, and evaluation of community nutrition programs and policies using a systems approach.

title: Public Administration
description: Processes and problems of managing government agencies, political context, policy impact, effects of bureaucratic organization; managing personnel and finances, evaluating effectiveness, controlling discretion.

title: Introduction to International Relations
description: Past and contemporary nation-state system; foreign policy behavior and processes, power, national interests, war, international law, organizations, economy, global problems and prospects. IAI Course S5 904.

title: Ethics in the Medical Community
description: Ethical issues arising in health care contexts and practices.

title: Foundations of Psychology
description: History; psychological methods and techniques; biological foundations of behavior; learning; motivation; development; personality; social; and psychopathology. IAI Course S6 900.

title: Health Psychology
prerequisitesRaw: PSYC 314 Minimum Grade of C OR BIOL 140 Minimum Grade of C OR (BIOL 240A Minimum Grade of C AND BIOL 240B Minimum Grade of C) AND PSYC 111 Minimum Grade of C
description: This course provides an introduction to the field of health psychology, which is concerned with the roles of behavioral and psychosocial factors on health and disease.

title: Physiological Psychology
prerequisitesRaw: PSYC 111
description: Biological foundations of behavior; structure and function of brain related to personality, behavior, health.

title: Social Class and Inequality
description: Extent and causes of social inequality. Attention to consequences of the sustained existence of such inequalities in our everyday lives.

title: The Sociological Study of Sexualities and Society
description: The sociological studies of sexualities with an emphasis on how sexualities are shaped by and operate within various institutions including medicine, economy, family, and education. Same as WMST 310.

title: Medicine, Health, & Society
prerequisitesRaw: Complete all Foundations Requirements: Foundation Writing 1, Foundation Writing 2, Foundation Speech Communication, Foundation Reasoning and Argumentation, and Foundation Quantitative Reasoning courses.
description: Critically investigates contemporary medical and scientific research/policy, examines social stratification, and considers influences on structural health outcomes, with a focus on health inequalities.

title: Health Care Issues in Social Work
prerequisitesRaw: BIOL 111
description: Examines contemporary health issues such as hypertension, diabetes, childhood obesity with emphasis on HIV/AIDS and how these diseases relate to populations at-risk.

title: Substance Abuse
prerequisitesRaw: (ENG 101 Minimum Grade of C OR ENG 101N Minimum Grade of C) OR ENG 101E Minimum Grade of C AND (ENG 102 Minimum Grade of C OR ENG 102N Minimum Grade of C)
description: The course is designed to help students understand the etiology, course, and treatment of substance use disorders and other addictions. Special emphasis will be given to biological, psychological, and sociological theories of addiction. Addictions will be viewed within a “person-in-environment” context.

title: Disability in Society
description: Overview of issues and services pertaining to disability in American society including biological, psychological, familial and social considerations. Not for Graduate Credit.

title: Mental Health
description: Exploration of mental health issues. Specific attention to the use of the DSM, diagnosis of mental illnesses and values and ethics in social work practice. NOT FOR GRADUATE CREDIT. Advisor consent required.
